column2: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to currency.

column6: Bitcoins are more similar to gold than they are to Dutch tulips in the 1630s.
column7: Confidence (10 being highest) in your knowledge of the issue associated with the question.

column4: At the moment Bitcoin is more of an investment than a medium of exchange and so is closer to gold. The reason is the price volatility.
column8: I think Bitcoin is not necessarily a bubble since it does have uses, eg, transferring value from Venezuela to the US.

column4: Except that you cannot make nice necklaces with bitcoins.

column8: Like bitcoin, the two assets have some intrinsic value.  Much of their price however reflects a bubble.  A draw
This feels like a classic bubble - my guess is 10 years from now they will be valueless.
Both gold and tulips are bubbles. Gold has a larger intrinsic value plus a long history as a safe haven asset.

column4: Bitcoins are a bubble. Gold embodies a bubble but has a fundamental industrial value. Currencies are a bubbles  backed by the government.
column8: Currencies are backed by tax collection.

column4: Bitcoins, like currency, are used as a means of payment. Gold is not. Gold has a fundamental value.
column8: Like the price of Dutch tulips in the 1630s, bitcoins' price seems to have a large bubble component. Gold's is likely smaller.

column4: Gold has intrinsic value. Bitcoin value, like currency, depends mainly on social or political conventions.
column8: Bitcoin has a payments function unlike those tulip bulbs

column4: A bitcoin is a private bet on becoming a (public) legal tender, and on earning the seignorage.
column8: Again, tulips had developed into a mutually accepted expression of value, and bulbs were seen as the key (algorithm) to replication/mining.

column4: It has no intrinsic value: like currency. Its liquidity: unclear, but similar w many currencies. It is a medium of exchange for criminals.
column8: Gold is also a medium of exchange though not a very liquid one.

column4: Bitcoin is neither close to gold nor to a currency. Studies show that its asset prices so far do not behave like gold or other currencies.
column8: Investors might be speculating on bitcoins being used in some future application, but there are many competitors or alternatives.

column4: Bitcoins have feature of currency, though volatility makes them undesirable except for speculation. Blockchain technology more important
column8: If I knew the answer I would take a position on them!

column4: Like gold, bitcoin has stable supply, unstable purchasing power, and no central bank to back it up /
column8: Little similarity to tulips besides the recent bubble-like price pattern

column4: They are not currency: no central bank involved and not used in every day transactions. Not exactly like gold: gold has other uses
column8: Tulips, from what I know, have very little other uses

column4: Bitcoins not an accepted means of exchange, nor unit of account, nor stable store of value. So not money.
column8: Bitcoins are bubble like tulips. And not even pretty to look at. Gold not bubble (and is rather pretty).

column4: Bitcoins are not commodity money (like gold) but rather fiat money (without the backing of a sovereign).
column8: Dutch tulips can hardly serve as commodity money.

column4: Bitcoins lack characteristics of fiat money (legal tender, trust in issuing state, good store of value, good medium of exchange)
column8: Gold has some durable intrinsic value (jewels). Bitcoins have none.

column4: Bitcoins are almost useless as currency... but like gold, in limited supply.
column8: Tulips are highly differentiated goods; bitcoin are not. But both bitcoin and tulips have no business being very valuable...

column4: The bitcoin supply is asymptotically fixed , as opposed to fiat money.
column8: Fantasy plays a large part in the pricing of bitcoin.

column4: On the relative similarity I agree but gold has actual uses (e.g. jewellery) which gives it some value. Bitcoin will likely end up worthless
column8: The tulips thing was a long time ago and there are various disagreements about it. But yes Bitcoin is more pure speculation than even gold.

column4: Bitcoins are a parallel currency, with no intrinsic value, very different from gold. But the supply is limited, like gold.
column8: Tulips were subject to a bubble, which also applies to bitcoins, and occasionally to gold.
